titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Received a letter from Mr Beasley at London, with the information that the British Government had formally rejected the Russian Mediation, and the report that Admiral Warren had been recalled for having listened to it. Mr Harris and Mr Lewis spent the Evening with us. Received a Note from Mr Gourieff, in answer to that I wrote him yesterday, and informing me that Mr Redwood’s affair was decided by the Committee of Ministers, but that the Journal was not yet signed— As soon as that shall be done he will communicate to me the result, and give his Orders at the Custom-house— He does not say the decision was favourable; but leaves me to infer it— I informed Mr Lewis that I had received this Note, requesting him to make it known to Mr Redwood.

2. Mr Redwood came to me from the Exchange, where he had seen Mr Pflug. This Gentleman’s brother arrived last Night from Gothenburg, to which place he came in the ship with Messieurs Gallatin and Bayard— He left them there on the 21st: of June, and came on by Land, as a Courier from Mr Daschkoff. In my walk after dinner I met Mr Gibson, and Mr Calhoun who had received letters from America to 8. May, by Mr Pflug— I afterwards met Mr Lewis walking with Mr W. S. Smith, and walked with them— Mr Calhoun told me the British had burnt Havre de Grace in Maryland, Fredericksburg in Virginia, and Georgetown in South-Carolina. Mr Montreal paid me a morning visit.

3. Mr Harris called upon me this morning, and told me that he had been last Evening into the Country to see Mr Pflug. He had not found him at his father’s house, because he was then in the City— But on his return home he had met and spoken to him— Mr Pflug had brought letters for him and for me, but had left them at Count Romanzoff’s. He had told him that the vessel they came in was the Neptune, Captain Lloyd Jones. They were at Gothenburg 21 June; about sailing that day for Cronstadt. Mr Milligan of Baltimore, Mr Dallas of Philadelphia, Mr Todd, Mrs Madison’s son, and a son of Mr Gallatin’s were in company with them— No Ladies— Mr Harris was quite uneasy that Count Romanzoff had not sent us our letters—thought he must be at Czarsko-Selo—proposed to send to his house and enquire if he was in town. He made a short visit, Mr Pflug having proposed to call on him this morning— He was scarcely out of the house, when I received a note from Count Romanzoff enclosing a letter from Messrs: Gallatin and Bayard, and one
from Mr Speyer at Stockholm—the first informs me of the appointment of those two Gentlemen, jointly with me as Envoys Extraordinary and Ministers Plenipotentiary, to negotiate a Peace with Great-Britain, under the Mediation of the Emperor of Russia—of their arrival at Gothenburg, and their intention to proceed as speedily as possible to St. Petersburg— Also that Mr Harris is appointed Secretary to the Legation— Mr Speyer’s letter, enclosed one for Mr Gallatin, open, for me to peruse.— I walked after dinner with Mrs Adams and Charles in the Summer-Gardens.

4. There was a party of Americans, 16. who went out and dined together at Pergali, nine or ten Versts out of town, on the Wyburg road, in celebration of our Independence day.— They gave me an informal invitation to make one of the Company, which I declined, chiefly because it was a Sunday— Mr Harris called on me before dinner— I read prayers for the third Sunday after Trinity, and Sterne’s Thanksgiving Sermon, upon the History of Asa—a Discourse applicable to the occasion— It is not however apparent from its contents on what occasion it was delivered, and the allusions to the Events of the times are so indistinct and general that I do not understand to what they particularly refer— I read further in Joly’s Geography of the Holy Land— There is a map of the Country adapted to the period, when the Conquest of Canaan was accomplished, and the Land was distributed among the tribes. I have compared the description, with the places, as laid down upon the map— It contains only a small proportion of the Cities named in the Scriptures, and many of those that are marked, are located by conjecture— The boundaries of the several tribes are so distinguished in the Bible that in a Map on a small scale, the site of remarkable places, royal, levitical, and refuge Cities cannot be much misplaced. The traces of several of them still subsist with their names— I walked after dinner in the Summer Gardens; the Evening was rainy— Mr Smith dined with the party— My Son John, whom God bless and preserve, is this day if it please God ten years old.— Charles 3 f. 6 3/4 i.

5. Mr Harris was here this morning, and again in the Evening. He also sent me the English Morning Chronicle of 9. 10 and 11. June. We made arrangements for going to Oranienbaum to meet Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard upon their arrival, which is to be hourly expected— Mr Pflug, came in the morning with Mr Harris— His father resides in Summer in a house opposite to that which we occupied on the Apothecary’s Island—across the river— He himself has been in America, about sixteen Months, and travelled from Boston to Savannah— He appears to be pleased with the Country.

6. This morning, Louis Aubin, a black man who formerly lived with me came to tell me that Quinzard, who was some time our Cook, and who left us, two months since to go and live at the British Ambassador’s, was lying there at the point of death, and had sent him to present to Mrs: Adams and me his last farewell; but Louis said he did not know whether on his return he should find him alive— I sent Pierre immediately to tell him how sincerely I felt for his situation, and to enquire if I could do any thing for him— He told Pierre that he wished to be removed to the House of a friend of his named Fournier, who could not receive him without a permission from the Master of the Police; and he desired me to endeavour to obtain it for him. I went to see Quinzard myself and found him in bed and unable to rise from it, not apparently so near his end as Louis had thought, but having probably not many days to live— His disease is a pulmonary consumption. He told me that Lord Cathcart’s Maitre d’Hotel named Bertrand had absolutely besieged him for four Months together to draw him away from my service, and now he totally neglected him—would not suffer his friends to come to attend and nurse him; nor even supply him with what he needed in his condition. He was very anxious to be removed, and to take with him his trunk which was in Bertrand’s possession, and contained four thousand Rubles in paper and some gold— I went to Fournier’s and ascertained that he was willing and desirous to receive Quinzard if the permission could be obtained. I then called at the House of General Gorgoly the Grand-Master of Police, but he was not at home— I returned and wrote him a Note requesting the permission for Quinzard’s removal, which I sent to Fournier to carry to him— I also called this morning on Mr: Meyer at the Wasili-ostroff, but he was not at home— Paid a visit to Mr Raimbert, and saw him and Mr: Montreal— Went to Mr Fishwick’s, an Englishman who keeps a school, where I have thoughts of placing Charles— Saw the school, and obtained information of the terms— But there is a Vacation of a fortnight to commence this week, and I postponed sending him there untill after its close— The rest of the day and Evening I was occupied with the English Morning Chronicles of which Mr Harris sent me this morning the file, from 28. May to 8 June.

7. Mr Fournier came to me this morning. He had delivered my note to the Grand-Master of the Police, General Gorgoly, who told him that for the permission to remove Quinzard, nothing was necessary but a certificate from the physician attending him, that his disorder was not infectious. I went to Dr Beverley’s to ask him for this certificate, but he was not at home— I then
called again to see Quinzard, whom I found weaker than he was yesterday, and doubtful himself whether he could now be removed— He also told me that he did not believe Dr. Beverley would give the Certificate— I sent twice in the course of the day to Beverley’s to enquire when I could see him, and he finally appointed 11 O’Clock to-morrow Morning— While I was out Mr Slade with a Mr Appleton called to see me; and Mr Treadwell.— I found at a Booksellers this afternoon, and purchased a copy of the German Translation of my Silesian Letters— I had never seen it— Mr Harris passed the Evening with us.

8. The father General of the Jesuits came this morning, and left with me a letter for father Grassi, President of the College at Georgetown, District of Columbia, and also 110 ducats, to make a remittance of 55 pounds Sterling for the value of which I am to remit an order payable to father Grassi.— Dr Beverley sent me a note, apologizing for not being able to see me at eleven O’Clock as he had appointed, he being obliged very suddenly to go to Cronstadt. I wrote him an answer, stating that what I wanted was the certificate required by the Police for the removal of Quinzard— I went soon after again to see Quinzard, whom I found worse than he was yesterday, bitterly complaining that he was totally neglected, and could obtain neither attendance nor any thing that he wanted, and fearful that he should die leaving all his effects in Bertrand’s hands. He was particularly and excessively anxious about a paper in the nature of a Will, which Bertrand had prevailed upon him about three weeks ago to sign.— I had been with him about half an hour when Dr. Beverley came in, bringing the certificate that I had requested, with him, and making now another apology for not having gone to Cronstadt as he had expected— He then gave me some account of Quinzard’s illness, and of his motives in concert with Bertrand, for putting Quinzard’s trunk with his money and effects into Bertrand’s possession—as also, for preventing Fournier, from having access to him— They were afraid that if he went to Fournier’s house, he would soon die there— Fournier would remain in possession of the money, and Quinzard’s brother to whom he meant to leave it would never see any of it— The Doctor hinted at the same time that Bertrand had doubts whether he could allow Quinzard any wages, since he had been at Lord Cathcart’s, and whether his, Beverley’s attendance should go to the account of the house or was to be charged to himself— He said that he had a yearly salary for his attendance at the house, and that at any rate he was willing to attend him gratuitously, even after his removal; and from motives of humanity— He also offered if I wished it to meet Dr Galloway and consult with him on the case— These were points on which I could not interfere, but I told Beverley my opinion that Quinzard must in equity be entitled to his wages, and that his attendance was of course chargeable to the house— The Certificate was the essential object— As soon as Quinzard was sure of having it, and Dr Beverley was gone he sent for Bertrand and asked for his trunk which was immediately brought—he had it opened, and the paper intended for a Will taken out— He struck out with his own hand all the legacies he had given— I advised him to make a regular and formal Will which he determined to do, and in the mean time to send his trunk to my house— I found the four thousand Rubles in paper, twelve Ducats, his watch; several pieces of silver, and his Cloathes in the trunk. It was afterwards sent to my house— He was in the afternoon removed to Fournier’s house; being carried in his bed.— Beverley told me he could live but a few days— While I was with him the Abbé Penguilli came in to see him, and an acquaintance of his named Vedel, both of whom advised him as well as I, to make a Will, and he sent for a sheet of stamped paper.— But he did not know whom to make his Executor, knowing no body in whom he could have sufficient Confidence.— I told him I would offer to be his Executor myself; but should perhaps very soon leave this Country, in which case he would have to substitute another.— He said he would ask the advice of the vieux prêtre (Penguilli) and make the Will to-morrow.— He told Bertrand that he owed him something for Oranges—and would pay him— Bertrand said it was best to defer it for when his account should be settled— He had left and yet intends to leave 3300 Rubles to his brother, Marc Quinzard who lives at Varédes a village near Meaux in Brie— He had another brother named François; but he went away many years ago to the army, and he knows not what has become of him.— Mr Lewis passed the Evening with us.

9. Mr Treadwell, called upon me this morning— He had a quantity of Cotton of the value he says of 100000 Rubles, in the hands of a merchant at Moscow named Müller— It was all burnt, at the Conflagration of Moscow, when the French took that City. Mr Treadwell came to ask my advice and opinion, whether he could not claim indemnity of the Russian Government, or of Mr. Müller—and whether Müller could recover of him about 10,000 Rubles which he had advanced him upon the deposit of the goods— I told him I thought his chance of recovering indemnity either from the Russian Government or from Müller very
small—that the Government was distributing some relief to the sufferers at Moscow and elsewhere, and that for a portion of that relief he might have a good claim— But that the losses were so great and extensive that the Government could not indemnify for them, and that they could probably not allow any stronger claim to the losses of foreigners than to those of their own people— Whether Muller was responsible to him for the worth of the Cotton destroyed, or he to Müller for the money advanced, were questions to be settled by the Laws of the Country, if they could not compromise them amicably, which he said was his desire— By the American Laws, and I supposed by those of this Country, Müller could not be accountable for property destroyed by a great and general Calamity without any fault on his part—whether he could recover monies advanced upon the pledge of that property, I could not positively say— It might depend upon the circumstances of the pledge, or the nature of the advances.— He said he had little expectation of recovering any thing, and would be glad to compromise for paying part of the money.— I went to see Quinzard at Fournier’s house— He was apparently not worse than yesterday and was much easier in mind— He has now a Doctor, and nursing entirely to his own satisfaction— The Doctor told him that if he had continued to take Beverley’s prescriptions he would not have lived eight days longer— He has not made his Will— I told him that if he chose he might name me as his Executor, and if I should go away, he might substitute another person in my place— I would undertake to remit the money to his brother— But I advised him to let me write immediately to his brother, so that he might have the prospect of hearing from him, and knowing that he was alive, as well as how and to whom the remittance for him could be made— I made these suggestions to him to reflect upon, and promised to call and see him again to-morrow— I also advised him to send and ask Bertrand for an immediate settlement of Accounts— Fournier came to my house, and took his linen from his trunk to carry to him— The rest of his Cloathes and the money remaining in it.— I walked after dinner with Mrs Adams and Charles, and afterwards in the Summer Gardens alone.

10. This morning Mr Fournier came for some of Quinzard’s linen which I gave him; and told me that he had been excessively ill in the Night;—so that he had thought he would not live through it— He also brought me his Will, which he made last Evening; and in which he has made me his Executor to remit the 3300 Rubles to his brother Mark Quinzard, and to pay the other legacies, and defray the Expences of his funeral— He left his Watch to my Son Charles— I went to see him about three O’Clock this afternoon— He complained of an excessive difficulty of breathing, and his speech was not perfectly distinct— There was a rattling in his throat which I also considered as a symptom of his approaching end; but his eyes were as clear as I ever saw them, and he appeared to be in full and perfect possession of his Understanding— I told him that I had received from Fournier his Will, and should there be occasion for it, would execute it to the best of my power— That with regard to the donation to my Son, which I sincerely hoped would not take effect, yet if it should, I accepted it for him with thanks— He expressed himself with warm gratitude for the kindness— I asked him if he wanted any thing further to send for it to my house— He said he was now in want of nothing; that every possible attention was paid to him, and if he had been treated so from the beginning of his illness he was sure he should now be well— He said there were a pair of earrings and two wedding rings in his trunk that did not belong to him— They belonged to a taylor who had pledged them to him for a loan of money— But he had since made him some waistcoats, and he wished me to send the trinkets to him, by Pierre, who knew where he lived. He told me he had sent to Bertrand to ask for a settlement of accounts; that Bertrand had been to him, but had evaded and deferred complying with his request— On returning home I found the rings and earrings in the trunk, and gave them to Pierre to carry to their owner. This afternoon the weather being fine, Mrs: Adams proposed to take a row-boat, and make a little party upon the river— We went, with Mr and Mrs Smith and Charles immediately after dinner. We took the boat at the Palace Corner, and being in it concluded to go to Mr Krehmer’s at Ochta— We reached there between 8 and 9 in the Evening and took tea there— Madam Mara once celebrated as a singer, and Mr Florio were there— Mr Krehmer came home soon after, with Miss Bock.— The Ladies had music— Mrs Mara’s voice is yet fine though she is near seventy years of age. We came home rapidly, with the wind and current in our favour— It was near twelve at Night when we landed. Pierre told me that Mr Fournier had been here to say that Quinzard died at a quarter past seven O’Clock this Evening.

11. The first thing I did this morning was to take an Inventory of the Cloathing and other Articles in Quinzard’s trunk; and to read over the Papers, which consisted altogether of Certificates, Passports, and a few letters from his family and two or three friends— He left France at the beginning of the Revolution, having previously been in the service of the Duke of Orleans. Since then he has lived at Copenhagen, Stockholm and here— His Certificates from the Chevalier de Souza, Portuguese Minister in Denmark, the Prince of Wurtemberg, Count Stedingk, Mr Garlike, Mr Merry, and others are all in terms of the highest commendation— My own was the last and equally strong. (v. 19. April last. p. 474) The letters from his family shew his affection and kindness for them— Fournier came to inform me of his arrangements for the funeral— I called at his house at 3 in the afternoon. Fournier was not at home— His wife told me that Quinzard had been sensible and talked untill his last moment— That he had mentioned his intention to give her his silver spoons as a token of memorial, and of thanks for her kindness to him— I went there again at seven in the Evening— The Abbé Penguilli performed a short preparatory service, after which the Body was removed to the Catholic Church, where the Messe is to be said at ten O’Clock to-morrow morning. The abbé apologized to me for not having known me again, when he met me the other day at Lord Cathcart’s house.— I read prayers this day for the fourth Sunday after Trinity, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the precept to follow Peace— In the Evening I walked in the Summer-Garden which was full of Company— I am this day forty-six years of age, and have had a special occasion by the scene of mortality before me to solemnize my thoughts for the day.— Poor Quinzard was but three years older than myself— Like me he was a stranger and a sojourner of in this land; but he had been driven from his native Country by that Hurricane, which swept away men of all Conditions alike; and though neither absolutely poor nor friendless, he was obliged in his last moments to call for my good offices, to enable him to die in Peace, and to save his brother from being plundered of the fruits of his Industry and Economy, which he destined for him. In undertaking to execute his last intentions I assumed a responsibility which Prudence might have directed me to decline; but my intentions were upright, and I pray that the purpose may be accomplished. Mr Meyer called on me this Morning, and I consulted him with regard to the necessity of having the Will registered— He thought it not necessary, and said that if I should, it would occasion both trouble and expence— I also consulted Mr Meyer about remitting the money left by Quinzard to his brother; and concerning some affairs of my own.

12. At ten O’Clock this morning I went with Charles to the Catholic Church, and attended the Messe, and the funeral service, over the remains of Quinzard, which we followed and saw deposited in the burying ground, called Smolensk on the Wasily-Ostrof, the same to which I have already been twice before— It is common to foreigners of all the religious denominations different from the Greek Church— Fournier had been in the morning and mentioned the final arrangements he had made for the funeral. He also brought a letter from the widow of a physician who had attended him in a former illness, claiming payment of 35 Rubles charged to him on her husband’s books. I directed Fournier to pay it; and told him I should give his wife the silver spoons that were in his trunk, and that he had told her he meant to give her— I would also give something to Louis Aubin, as he had expressed such an intention.— After my return home this morning I had a long visit from Mr Harris— After dinner I walked in the Summer-Gardens— Mrs Smith was unwell, and confined the whole day to her chamber.

13. I went this morning to Mr Meyer’s; took up Mr Smith’s Note to him, and left with him money to purchase a Bill of exchange upon Paris for 3300 Roubles to be remitted to Quinzard’s brother— Mr Meyer told me that the rumours prevailing led to the expectation of Peace on the European Continent.— That the orders of marching to the army of reserve had been countermanded, and that the Minister at War had ordered all the barracks here to be prepared for the reception of the troops. He added that Princess Kutuzoff had told some person the peace was already signed. Mr Lewis and Mr Harris passed the Evening with us— Mr Harris says there is an order from the Police to suppress the Caricatures against the French; but that immense preparations are making for the renewal of hostilities at the end of the armistice. Mr Fournier was here this morning, and I settled with him the Account for the expences of Quinzard’s funeral; and gave him the spoons he had intended for his wife. Forestier, and Louis Aubin were here likewise and I gave them, what he left to the first, and a remembrance, as he said he had intended to the last.— The monthly settlement of accounts, with these occasional incidents occupied the day so that I had time neither to read nor write— I walked after dinner in the Summer Gardens, which are the most pleasant part of the City in warm summer weather; as is now just commencing.

14. We all went out and dined at Mr Krehmer’s at Ochta. Mr Lewis and Mr Willing, Dr: Beresford, and the two Gisborne’s were there— Miss Bock resides there— We went and returned late— I walked from the Summer Garden Bridge home.— I finished this day the settlement of Quinzard’s affairs, excepting the remittance to his brother, and his accounts while in Lord Cathcart’s service, which I suppose cannot be settled.

15. I called last Friday at Countess Colombi’s, and looked at the late General Pardo’s Books which are left there for Sale, some of which I inclined to purchase; but Mr Koehler had estimated them at such excessive prices that I have hesitated at taking any of them. Mr Lys came to me this morning to ask if I had come to a determination. I agreed to take the Oratores Graeci and the Plutarch of Reiske—a Diodorus Siculus, of Wesseling, and a Strabo of Siebenkees; an Edition not yet completed— There was another list upon which I suspended my determination for a week or ten days— The Books are all fixed at prices equal at least to their original cost and binding, some of them considerably higher— Mr Strugoffschikoff my Landlord came to enquire whether I intended to take the house for the third year of my lease— I could not answer him positively. I told him it was probable I might leave the Country in a Month or six weeks— I expected hourly to receive definitive orders, and Would then give him a definitive Answer.— He talked politics as usual— Is much displeased with the armistice, and knows not why it was signed. Thinks there is a want of firmness and of energy at the allied head-quarters, and that Bonaparte’s good fortune consists in his having no great man to oppose him— After dinner I rode out, and walked with Mrs Adams and Charles at Catherinenhoff— Mr Lys lent me a French system of Stenography or short hand, by Clément; but on a cursory examination of it, I do not find it better than Byron’s— There are however in it some ideas which may be useful by way of improvement, and Clément’s system may be best adapted for the French language— He has characters for the vowels as well as for the consonants—the want of them is an imperfection in Byrom.

16. Morning visit from Mr Montreal. Mr Gibson came and informed me that he expected to go, next Wednesday, in a Swedish vessel from Cronstadt directly to Stockholm— I promised to ask for a Passport for him, to be ready on Tuesday Evening— After dinner I went with Mrs: Adams and Charles to Kammenoi-Ostroff and we walked in the Strogonoff Garden— Mr Harris whom I met as I was walking home passed the Evening with us.— He brought three Morning Chronicles, one of which contains the Treaty of subsidy between Sweden and England.

17. I was very unwell the whole of this day. Attempted to walk before breakfast but was obliged to return immediately home. The day was wasted in idleness. I only read the french system of Stenography lent me by Mr Lys— It is a composition formed of parts selected from several of the English systems— After dinner I rode out with Mrs Adams and Charles, five or six Miles on the Road to Czarsko Zelo.

18. The Senator Count Kwastoff called upon me this morning with some packets for Mr Swienin one of the Gentlemen attached to the Russian Legation in America. He told me that they contained nothing but poetry— Verses of his own composition. That he had spoken of America, and of Franklin in this poem; and had cited and translated the famous latin Line about him Eripuit coelo fulmen sceptrumque tyrannis— He wished that somebody could be found to snatch the Sceptre from Bonaparte— He heard the Armistice had been prolonged, and a letter from General Barclai de Tolli had been published, addressed to the Minister of the interior Kosodavleff, saying that the army was in the best possible condition, and ready to meet the Enemy again, unless peace should be made; which implies that there is a negotiation for Peace— He further told me that the Minister of War, General Gortschakoff was his wife’s brother—that he himself had been patronized and befriended by Suworroff, and had a great many letters from him, which he would publish; but they contained sarcastic remarks upon many individuals, such as the late Marshal Kutuzoff, Bezboradko, the Zuboffs and others so that they could not be published— I read prayers for the 5th: Sunday after Trinity, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the precept to Search the Scriptures. I read also letters of father Joly on the City of Jerusalem, and on the Temple of Solomon— Walked after dinner in the Summer Gardens; returning home I met on the Quay Countess Colombi and her Sister Clementine— They came to town to go to morrow to Czarsko Zelo to attend the benediction of the Standards of the regiment of Spanish deserters.

19. Mr Harris called upon me this morning, and spent the Evening with us— He is in great agitation and anxiety at the delay in the arrival of our Gentlemen from America; and I begin to feel no small concern on the same account— While he was with me I received a letter from Mr Speyer at Stockholm, mentioning that they were on the 24th of June at Elseneur— His letter anticipates that they
would have a long passage, from the late prevalence of Easterly winds in the Baltic— They have been in that quarter here with scarcely the interruption of a day the whole Month. I walked with Charles in the Morning, and after dinner alone in the Summer Garden— There I met and walked with Mr Boucher who told me that he was intending to publish a Romance, called “the wandering Jew.” He gave me a general idea of the plan of his work, which is indeed indicated by its title— It is to be in three Volumes, and he thinks will be very amusing— He asked me many questions about America, which he is entirely convinced was known to the antients.— I wrote this morning to Count Romanzoff, for a Passport for Mr Gibson, and the rest of the day was employed in preparing letters to send by him.

20. Mr Harris came about 2 O’Clock this afternoon with a letter from Mr Gallatin written at Reval the day before yesterday— They have had contrary winds ever since they left Gothenburg, and after beating up the Baltic a fortnight against it they put into the Port of Reval last Wednesday, the 14th. they waited there three days, for a change of wind, which not having taken place, they concluded to come on by land— They were to leave Reval at 7 in the Evening of the 18th. and expected to be three days on the road, and request Mr Harris to send some person to meet them at Strelna— The ship is to come up with the first fair wind.— I received the Pass port for Mr Gibson— He was here in the morning and again in the Evening, when I gave him his Passport and all the Packets I had for him including those for Mr Daschkoff, Baron Strogonoff, and Mr Swienin— He is to leave the City at 5 O’Clock to-morrow morning, and expects to sail from Cronstadt in the course of the day.— Mr Harris also passed part of the Evening here.— I wrote to the Secretary of State to inform him of the arrival of the Envoys at Reval, and dispatched the letter by Mr Gibson— I received yesterday from Mr Gourieff the Minister of Finance a definitive answer concerning Mr Redwood’s affair— The confiscation of the hats is confirmed but the fine is remitted.

21. I had a long morning visit from Mr Lewis— Just after 4 in the afternoon Mr Harris came in and told me that Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard had just arrived— I immediately went to see them at the lodgings he has taken for them— I invited them, and Mr Milligan, Mr Dallas, and Mr Gallatin junr: who are with them, to go home with me and dine; but they excused themselves, being much fatigued, and having been three Nights without sleep— I sat with them about an hour in which they gave us the latest information from America, and I communicated to them the general state of affairs here— They gave me a large bundle of letters and dispatches from the United-States, which with the exception of an hour at dinner, I was employed untill ten at Night in reading.— I thank Almighty God, for the favours communicated to me by these dispatches, and I pray for the gracious aid of his Spirit to discharge with zeal, integrity, and discretion the new duties required of me.

22. Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard called upon me this morning, and we had some conversation together on the mode of proceeding upon our business— The first object is that they should be presented to the Chancellor, for which some essential preparatory arrangements require a delay of one or two days— I dined at the Count’s, mentioned to him the arrival of my Colleagues, and requested an interview with him, for some particular Conversation— He appointed to morrow 1. O’Clock P.M. Baron Blome gave me two letters, which he said came from the Emperor’s Head-Quarters, and had been handed to him for me by a person of the Gourieff family— I suppose they came through Count Nesselrode— I found one of them was from General La Fayette, and the other from the Senator, Count Destutt de Tracy, asking the use of my influence, to obtain the release upon parole or the exchange of Mr de Tracy’s son an officer of infantry taken prisoner last Winter with General Augereau and now at Tamboff, between Moscow and Astrachan— Count Romanzoff told me the news of Lord Wellington’s new victory in Spain, at Vittoria, and I saw the dispatch which he had just received from Count Lieven, announcing it— After dinner, the Count introduced me to Prince Alexander Kurakin, late Russian Ambassador in France, who has been only a few days here, and to whom this dinner was principally given— I had some conversation with him, concerning the Americans whom he has seen, and to whom he was always very attentive and obliging.— He also told me that he had received information from Mr Warden, concerning the archives of the Russian Legation, which had been deposited with Mr Barlow—that they were safe in Mr Warden’s possession, and that he the Prince had requested they should be transferred to Mr Barlow’s successor whenever he should arrive. I returned home on foot, for some of the Police officers had taken my Coachman from his seat, for having run across a Droshky, the driver of which was drunk, and the Carriage was stopped so that it could not come to me.— Messrs: Gallatin, Bayard, Harris, Lewis, Milligan, Dallas, and young Gallatin, Willing and Redwood, dined at our house— And walked in the Evening round the City.

23. Mr Harris brought the Credential letter of the extraordinary mission, of which a copy and translation are to be delivered to Count Romanzoff, and he asked me to make the Translation, which I promised.— I went to Countess Colombi’s to make some inquiries concerning the Major de Tracy, whose liberation I was requested to endeavour to obtain— I wished to see Mr Zea, but he was not at home— I saw Mr Lys, and Don Francisco— They had furnished money to Mr de Tracy, and I enquired whether they knew any thing further concerning him; which how ever they did not.— At one I called as by appointment upon Count Romanzoff, and told him that I had received instructions from the American Government to remain here under the Commission which I have hitherto held, and that I had been mistaken in supposing that my Colleagues had other destinations, independent of the mission here— My conjecture had been founded on the doubt whether the President would have appointed this Mission solely, upon the expectation that the mediation would be accepted by the British Government.— But I was now instructed that the President, considering the acceptance by the British as probable, though aware that if they should reject it, this measure might wear the appearance of precipitation, thought it more advisable to incur that risque, than the danger of prolonging unnecessarily the War, for six or nine Months, as might happen, if the British should immediately have accepted the Mediation, and he should have delayed this step untill he was informed of it. And a great object with him was to manifest not only a cheerful acceptance on the part of the United States, but in a signal manner the sentiments of consideration and respect for the Emperor, and to do honour to the motives on which he offered his Mediation— Another Gentleman, Mr Crawford was appointed Minister to France. The Count said he regretted much that there was such reason to believe the British would decline the Mediation; but on transmitting the copy of our Credential letter to the Emperor, he would determine whether to renew the proposal, as the Opposition in England might make it an embarrassing charge, against the Ministry if they should under such Circumstances reject it— He spoke of the taking of York-town in Upper Canada, by General Dearborn; and desiring me not to mention him as an Authority, added that he was informed the British Government had determined in consequence of that event to send more troops to America.— I told the Count there were two other objects not connected with either of my public Capacities here, but upon which I found it necessary to speak to him— The first was concerning a payment made to the owners of a Vessel to which a black man belonged, who had entered into the Emperor’s service— This payment was made, by way of indemnity for the detention of the vessel— I had been directed by a verbal message from the Minister of the Police Balascheff to offer this indemnity; and I related to the Count the circumstances of the man’s having got into the Emperor’s service— The Count asked what the amount of the payment was— I said it was about 700 dollars, amounting to more than 3000 Rubles— He said he would write upon the subject to Mr Balacheff— The other subject I observed was still more remote from my official functions, for it related to a French Prisoner— My only motives and my excuse for speaking of it to him were humanity and gratitude. General La Fayette had written to me, requesting me to endeavour to obtain a favour for a relation of his a Mr de Tracy, now at Tamboff, and taken last Winter with Augereau— On the score of gratitude for General La Fayette’s services to my Country, and of a very old personal friendship for him, I was ardently desirous of rendering him any service in my power— What he, and the Senator Count de Tracy the Prisoner’s father wanted was either an exchange, or a release on parole— The Count said he did not think it would be possible— The french had refused to listen to any proposition for exchange— An English Officer named Willoughby had come here last Summer and offered his services— He had been sent to Count Wittgenstein’s army, and by lending his horse to a wounded Russian, whom he had even carried some way upon his shoulders, he had fallen into the Enemy’s hands— The Emperor had asked to have him exchanged, and had been positively refused—in consequence of which he had resolved he would listen to no applications of a similar Nature— However if I would give him the Officer’s name, he would write to the Emperor about it; and although there was no prospect of obtaining an exchange, there might possibly be a permission for his removal—perhaps for him to come to St: Petersburg; that I might then enter into correspondence with him, and his situation might be alleviated— I replied that I would give him the name, and as it was altogether a favour I was asking, I should be grateful for any thing that might be granted— The Count agreed with me to receive my Colleagues with me at 11. to-morrow Morning; and said that at 12 he should set out for Czarsko Zelo, to spend two or three days there— I spoke of the presentation of my Colleagues and myself to the Empresses— He said that the
Empresses in the Country had received two or three private Strangers; but that they could not receive persons in such a public character as that of Envoys Extraordinary, unless they had been previously received by the Emperor; or untill the Emperor should give his orders on receiving the copy of the Credential letter— He might perhaps direct that the Gentlemen should be considered as having delivered the letter to him in person— Or if he should return here as it was sometimes said he soon intended, we might then really deliver it— This is a change of opinion since the Count spoke with me on this subject before— In General there appears a coolness in his manner which leads me to suspect that the Emperor himself is not well pleased at the eclat which this mission will give to the British refusal of his mediation— The Count’s politeness is as marked and warm as ever, but there is a reserve and sollicitude in the manner, which I regret to perceive— I went from his house to the lodgings of my Colleagues and informed them of the time fixed for presenting them to the Count— Mr Gallatin then put into my hands the three Full-powers which contain our Commissions— One to negotiate the Peace with Britain, under the Mediation of the Emperor of Russia— One to negotiate a Treaty of Commerce with Britain given for the contingency that the pacific Negotiation should be successful— In these two Mr Gallatin is the first Commissioner, and I am the second—the third power is to negotiate a Treaty of Commerce with Russia, in which as well as in the Credential Letter, my name is the first and Mr Gallatin’s the second. This arrangement Mr Gallatin told me was made intentionally, and I consider it as a mark of delicate attention in the President towards me, though I should have been perfectly satisfied had Mr Gallatin’s name been first in all the papers— I took the Powers for treating of Peace with Britain, and of Commerce with Russia, home with me, and made translations of them and of the Credential letter which I carried to Mr Harris’s, when I went to dinner— We all dined there; together with Messrs: Lewis, Willing, Redwood, and Calhoun— Mr Gallatin corrected my translations of the papers, and after dinner we took a long walk over the Isaac Square Bridge, and round by the new Exchange— I came home between 9 and 10 in the Evening.

24. At eleven this morning, I went with Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard to Count Romanzoff’s, and presented them to him.— He received us in his Salloon above Stairs, with his usual Courtesy— After some conversation upon the familiar and ordinary topics, Mr Gallatin gave him the copies and translations of the Credential letter, and the two Powers, observing that we should address a Note to him on the subject; but that we now furnished him with the papers to give him an immediate view, by anticipation of the extent of our Powers— I mentioned to him that the object of one of them was to form a Treaty of Commerce with Russia; upon which he answered that we might be very sure of being listened to in every thing we might have to say here. He said there might be reason to hope that the British Government would be more inclined to negotiate now, as upon the only remaining great object of dispute with us, he understood Congress had lately passed a Law, which must take away a great part of the British grounds of complaint. Mr Gallatin added that besides this Law, if any thing further was necessary to tranquilize Britain upon the point of which she complained, we were authorised to agree to any expedient that might be proposed, and which would be compatible with the rights of an Independent Nation— The only point indispensible on our part, being to obtain a stipulation which should protect our Seamen from impressment— The Count spoke of the late capture of York in Upper-Canada, and asked if it would not give us the command of the lakes— Mr Gallatin said we might hope it would lead to the occupation of Upper-Canada; and that the command of the Lakes could not be contested against us after we had built vessels upon them. The British having always had a few vessels there, and we none, untill the War— I gave the Count a paper with the name and situation of Mr de Tracy, on it as he had yesterday requested— He said he would attend to it, and I might be sure nothing would prevent the application from succeeding but what he had mentioned to me— On our taking leave both the gentlemen gave him private letters which they had for him from Mr Daschkoff— He asked us on what day we should be disengaged to dinner— He should return from Czarsko Zelo on Tuesday; would Wednesday or Thursday suit us—we said either—then he said he should take the shortest day, and would send us Cards for Wednesday. I went home with the gentlemen, and sat a couple of hours with them— We agreed to meet on Monday at 11 O’Clock at my house, to discuss the project of a Note to the Count, and to pay personal visits to the foreign Ministers on that and the next day. Mr Gallatin enquired of me on what footing Mr Smith was here and I told him of the two Commissions he had received, and of the number of times I had written to the Department of State concerning him without receiving any Answer— He said that the State
Department always had that habit they never decided any thing—always postponed. But by the Law of 2 May 1810 no payment could be allowed at the Treasury for a Secretary of Legation, or private Secretary, unless regularly appointed with the concurrence of the Senate— That Law of 2 May 1810. Mr Bayard spoke of as Bradley’s Law— Mr Gallatin said it was Robert Smith’s Law, or rather, the Smith’s law; it was introduced the very last day of the Session, carried by Mr Burwell the organ of the Smith’s in the House of Representatives, into the House and read three times on the same day—presented to the President at ten O’Clock at Night with a number of other Bills, at the moment when the Session was closing— And afterwards R. Smith had affected to make this very law an Article of attack upon the President— I said I had seen in an Answer to Mr Smith’s publication a statement that it would probably be repealed. Mr Gallatin said that the President had made no appointment under it. Mr Bayard thought that Mr T. Barlow had been appointed— Mr Gallatin said he had been nominated; but some difficulty had occurred, and the nomination had been withdrawn— For in the late dispute between Mr Warden and young Barlow at Paris, Mr Monroe had told Mr Gallatin that Barlow had been right; because he supposed himself to have an appointment— I observed that a provision was made in all the appropriation Laws for a Secretary of Legation here; and no other appointment having been made, I had paid the Salary to Mr Smith, constantly requesting and expecting Instructions— I had at least supposed they would have brought some, but there is not a word upon the subject in the dispatches they have brought.— It was between 3 and 4 O’Clock when I came home— After dinner I went with Charles to Mr Fishwick’s— His term commences again next week, and Charles is to go to him on Tuesday.— I called at the Lodgings of my Colleagues, but they were all abroad.

25. I read prayers this morning for the sixth Sunday after Trinity, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the text “O come let us worship and fall down before him:—for he is the Lord our God.”— Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard, Mr Milligan and Mr Dallas made a morning visit— They had been to the Monastery of St: Alexander Nefsky, and to the Church of St: Isaac, where they had heard the Russian Mass, and seen several children baptized. I was occupied the remainder of the day in writing; but walked after dinner in the Summer Gardens.

26. Mr Gallatin called upon me about noon, and sat with me two or three hours. Mr Bayard is so unwell that he is confined to the house, and could not come out.— He feels the effect of the Neva Water— Mr Gallatin brought me a first sketch of a Note to be presented to Count Romanzoff, announcing our appointment and mission for the Negotiation of Peace— He had drawn it up in French— I made an English Translation of it, and added an extract from the last Instructions to me from the department of State on the same subject— I spoke to Mr Gallatin respecting a passage home for Mr Smith, on board of the vessel in which they came; which he said would deserve to be considered. I asked him also respecting the Mates and Seamen of the American vessels at Cronstadt; but he thought few or none of them could get a passage in her— The Passport from the British Admiral was only for her to come out; and another would be necessary for her to return home, the Passport was only for the vessel and her crew—the Ministers and their Secretaries— So that all the Gentlemen who came out with them had been registered at the Department of State as their Secretaries— Messrs: Gallatin and Son, Harris, Appleton, Cabot, Calhoun, Dallas, Hurd, Lewis, Milligan, Pflug, Redwood, Stanwood, Wainwright and Willing dined with us— Messrs: Bayard, Bates, Endicott and Treadwell were invited, but could not come— Mrs: Smith was taken so unwell this morning, that she could not come to table— I walked in the Evening to the Summer Gardens.

27. I took Charles at 9 O’Clock this morning to Mr Fishwick’s, where I placed him at a day school. He returned home at 6 in the Evening well satisfied with it— I have been hitherto myself his teacher, but shall henceforth not have time for his lessons— I wish him also to be habituated to the regularity and order of school-hours, and to have a greater portion of his time occupied than has been hitherto. Captn: Stanwood called upon me and enquired whether a Russian Vessel with Russian goods can go to the Havanna— I told him I would make enquiry— I think it cannot— Mr Harris and Mr Montreal were here, but I could not see them— Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard came, and we had a conference of about three hours— Mr Gallatin took his first sketch of our proposed Note to Count Romanzoff, with the translation, and additional paragraphs I had drawn up, for the purpose of making a final draft of the Note. Mr Gallatin had proposed the suggestion of some ideas on the probable rejection of the Mediation, by Great Britain— I had accordingly introduced them— But Mr Bayard thought it would be best to make no reference to this prospect at-all, and Mr Gallatin finally came over to his opinion— I desired them to determine it between themselves, being ready either to introduce or omit those suggestions as they should think best.— We had much Conversation upon a variety of topics connected with the objects of our Mission—
Mr Bayard though much better than he was yesterday, was still so unwell that he thought it would be best to postpone our further visits to the Corps diplomatique for some days.— After dinner I rode out with Mrs Adams and Charles to Catherinenhoff.

28. I took Charles again to school this morning. Mr Gallatin called upon me about one O’Clock— Mr Bayard being still unwell did not come— He had made a draft of a Note to be sent to Count Romanzoff differing still from that which Mr Gallatin and I had prepared— We now compared them all together, and agreed upon one to be composed of the three; and which is to be given to Mr Harris to make out a fair Copy to be sent— We dined at Count Romanzoff’s with the usual diplomatic company. Prince Kurakin, and Count Markoff, and the Generals Tormassoff and Armfelt were there— The Duke de Serra-Capriola came after dinner. Count Maistre was absent— I sat next to the Chevalier Bardaxi-Azara, on one side, and General Gorgoly on the other— Baron Blome told me that the Armistice was prolonged to 10. August, with the additional six days of notice. In the mean time a preliminary to a Congress was to meet at Prague— Count Metternich from Austria as the Mediator, Count de Narborne from France—Arnstett from Russia—Humboldt from Prussia, and Lord Walpole from England— They were to try to agree upon a Basis for Negotiation, and if they could the Congress was to assemble at Prague— In the mean time it was said, that an eventual Alliance offensive and Defensive between Russia and Austria was concluded— I asked how the Mediation and the Alliance were conciliated together— He said by the Alliances being eventual— He thinks however the Negotiation will come to nothing— That Napoleon is only gaining time and will finish by breaking all up, and renewing the War— Mr Bardaxi as we sat at table told me that Mr Dallas had a letter for him from the Spanish Minister Non-reconnu at Washington.— I said that it was to be hoped he would be reconnu in time— The American Government had perhaps thought the example of Spain a good one, and having had three or four years during the War of our Revolution a Minister Non-reconnu in Spain, had reserved the acknowledgment of the Spanish Minister untill the end of the contest for Spain— He said Spain had not to be sure acknowledged our Minister, but had aided us in our War; I said we had also aided them in theirs: particularly in the Article of Provisions; which he admitted— I spoke to General Armfeldt after dinner, and requested him to repeat my thanks to General Aminoff, for the Medal he lately sent me— Count Romanzoff told me that he had written upon the subject of my application in behalf of Mr de Tracy, not to the Emperor, but to Count Araktcheieff, because the Emperor might have thought he had given the order to permit Mr de Tracy to come to St: Petersburg, and have said it was very well, and not have answered the letter— But Count Araktcheieff must answer his letter— He had therefore written him that my request was that Mr de Tracy might be exchanged; or permitted to go home on Parole— That he had not thought himself authorized to give me any expectation this could be granted, but that he had urged his wish to do as much as possible as a favour to me, and asked that Mr de Tracy might be allowed to come to St: Petersburg, and put into my Custody; which he hoped would be obtained— I had some conversation also on general political subjects with Count Soltykoff. I took a short walk in the Evening— The Neptune arrived this day at Cronstadt.

29. I took Charles to school this morning; he went with some reluctance— On returning home I found the father General of the Jesuits Brzozowsky, who had called to offer his congratulations on the arrival of my Colleagues. I had stop’d at Mr Harris’s to tell him that Count Romanzoff had fixed twelve O’Clock this day to receive us. He shewed me his Commission which is only for the Negotiation of Peace and of the Treaty of Commerce with England— At Noon I went with him and presented him as Secretary to the Mission to Count Romanzoff. He received us with his usual courtesy and urbanity— I asked him if the Rumours of the prolongation of the Armistice untill the 10th: of August, besides the six days Notice were true? He said he had no doubt they were, but that neither he, nor the minister of War, had one syllable of information, not merely of the fact, but even of there being any such intention— He said he had received yesterday a letter from Lord Cathcart, the first he had written him since he had been at the Emperor’s Head-Quarters— He notified him of the intention of the British Government to send a Secretary of Embassy to remain here at St: Petersburg, and in the mean time requested him to deliver Passports on the application of Mr Bailey (the British Consul.) He had certainly never refused Mr Bailey any Passports and did not know why this request was addressed to him— The Count expressed without reserve his disapprobation of the armistice and of its prolongation. He said that every thing was done too much in a hurry to be well done— I said that I supposed he would not consider the Congress at Prague to settle whether there should be a Congress at Prague, as an overhasty measure— Yes—he thought it was— There was a very simple preliminary question— Was a general Peace at this time possible? Every body must answer—No!—it was
obviously Napoleon’s object by the armistice to gain time, and nothing more— He would improve that time to the utmost, for his own advantage, and he the Count therefore thought it was wrong to let him have the opportunity— Another instance of hastiness the Count said was in the Council of Administration which had been very formally organized for the Countries between the Oder and the Elbe— Je me reproche encore ma gaieté, said he when Count Löwenhielm came to me very gravely to give me Notice that his Court had appointed a member of the Swedish Council to take his seat in this Council of Administration— He seemed to expect that it was a step which would have met with some opposition, for he laid it down somewhat elaborately that according to the Spirit of the Alliance, Sweden considered herself as having a right to appoint a member to the Council of Administration— I laughed and told him I was very glad to hear it. That I presumed the more members there were appointed to the Council of Administration, the more there was to administer. But really there seems now but little for the Council of Administration to do— If they were an Assembly of Solon’s, it is but a small number of People indeed that they can make happy by their Laws— I asked if Count Löwenhielm had arrived at the Head-Quarters— He had no news of his arrival, and the messenger he had given to accompany him had not returned— After going home with Mr Harris I called upon my Colleagues— Mr Bayard was gone out; I saw only Mr Gallatin, with whom I had two hours of Conversation, all upon general subjects— Mr Todd came in while I was there—he arrived in the ship the Evening before last, and came up from Cronstadt last Evening— I desired Mr Gallatin to consult Mr Bayard on the propriety of our taking notice of this Negotiation for a general Peace, of which there appears to be now a considerable prospect.— On the supposition that Great-Britain should eventually reject the Mediation of Russia, and that the Congress for a general Peace should be held, I thought it should excite our particular attention— Mr Gallatin asked me to make the draft of a Note to Count Romanzoff, on the Subject of the Treaty of Commerce with Russia— I made one immediately after dinner, and took it to their lodgings, but found nobody at home. Mr: Lewis and Mr Redwood passed the Evening with us. Mr Redwood intends to go in about a fortnight, and I promised to obtain for him a Courier’s Passport.

30. On returning this morning from taking Charles to school I called at the lodgings of my Colleagues, but found nobody there. They came to my house about Noon, with Mr Harris, having the Note to Count Romanzoff concerning the Negotiation for Peace, prepared—we signed it; and Mr Harris took it with him, and sent it to the Count. It has been the work of a week, and might have been done by either of us in two hours— It is a sufficient specimen of the method of negotiating by Commissions— In the multitude of Counsellors, there is safety, but there is not dispatch. I gave at the same time to my Colleagues, my draft of the Note concerning the Treaty of Commerce with Russia— It was in French; and Mr Bayard wished to have it in English before he could take it into consideration— Mr Gallatin returned it to me to make the English translation— At one I called upon them, and we went to pay visits to the foreign Ministers—to Baron Blome, and the Chevalier Bardaxi-Azara in the Country—to Count Maistre, Captain Guedes, and Mr Zea and Don Francisco Colombi, in town— We found nobody at home.— We dined with Mr Harris, en famille—the whole legation, including Mr Todd, and Dr Loughton who came up from the ship last Evening— My Colleagues went in the Evening with Mr Harris and paid a visit to Princess Beloselsky; I walked in the Summer Garden.— This morning a Captain Russell and a Mr Ford came and enquired whether they could have a passage home to America in the ship— I supposed it not possible, but referred them for an answer to Mr Gallatin, and Mr Bayard. Mr Hurd also came, with a letter from Mr Gray, directing him to consult me respecting the disposal of some Indigo that he has here, in the hands of a Mr Wright, an English Merchant. I gave him the best advice I could, according to my judgment upon the information that I have; but I told him I was in such a public situation that I might hereafter be incompetent to advise him without disclosing a knowledge of Circumstances which it might be my duty to withhold— In that case I should be under the necessity of declining to advise him— In every other I should be happy to give any advice which might tend to promote Mr Gray’s interests.— Captain Jones of the Neptune was expected up from Cronstadt the whole of this day; but did not arrive— I wrote him a note yesterday, requesting him to bring up what he has for me and deliver it to Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner.

31. On returning from taking Charles to school, I stopp’d at the lodgings of my Colleagues, and left with Mr Gallatin the English Translation of the Note to Count Romanzoff concerning the Treaty of Commerce with Russia. I had morning visits from Mr Montreal, Mr Wainwright and Mr Willing, Captain Stanwood and his Son.— I told Captain Stanwood what Count Romanzoff and the Chevalier Bardaxi had answered me, on the question whether a Russian vessel laden with Russian produce would be admitted at the Havanna. Messrs: Gallatin, Bayard, Harris, Milligan, Dallas, and Gallatin junr. dined with us— After dinner Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard went out with me to Countess Colombi’s and the Duke de Serra Capriola’s in the Country— It was near midnight when we returned. We found the Countess with her Sister Clementine and Miss Carnerero; without Company— The Duke and Duchess were also alone. I wrote to Quinzard’s brother, and to Messrs: Hottinguer and Co: at Paris, remitting to them the Bill of exchange furnished me by Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner.

Day. My ordinary course of occupations has been diversified by the occurrences of the past month, and particularly by the arrival of my Colleagues. My rising hour has been unsettled between 5 and 8 O’Clock in the Morning; but generally between 6 and 7.— I read and write before Breakfast as I have long been accustomed— During the first part of the Month I continued Charles’s lessons, which employed about three hours every day— Having now placed him at school I take him there at Nine every morning; it is about two miles, and I take it for my morning walk— Breakfast on my return, about 10.— Meet my Colleagues, at their lodgings, write, receive or pay visits untill 5 in the afternoon, when we dine— Walk about two hours after dinner, or ride into the Country. Receive Evening visitors untill Midnight, or retire between 10 and 11.— I close this Volume of my diary, containing four years within four days of my life, with Sentiments of Gratitude to God for all the favours, preservations and blessings received at his hands during that period; of humble Resignation under the afflictions which his wise Providence has mingled in my cup, and with conscious sorrow for the deficiencies and omissions of improvement, of the time which has been indulged me. Imploring at the same time his further blessing upon my wife, my Parents, my children, my friends and my Country, and the whole world of mankind, and especially asking for the aid of his Spirit that my future life may be more thoroughly devoted to his honour and glory and to usefulness on Earth.
